comments.commentBody:
That was a fun one. Nice to see JCampbell and NYoung in the puzzle.

Other than that, ________ (. . . according to a tennis player) much to add.

Except there's also ____-____-__-______-__-_-________ (. . .according to the Playmates), now dancing around in my third ear.

I realize Valentine's Day calls for cutsy (popcorn sharing) or syrupy (many splendored thing) quotes, which Matt and Pete give us nicely in todays puzzle. But the curmudgeon in me wants at least one rather cynical view like Ambrose Bierce's Love: A temporary insanity curable by marriage.
I did enjoy the clever clues like gym for "rep center". Very good work Matt, Pete, and Will. Happy Heart's Day!

The answer to 1 across and the clue do not match correctly. The clue is NOT a geometric series, it is a convergent infinite sum, because of the plus signs. In order for the clue to be correct, and in order for the numbers to be a series, all the plus signs need to be replaced by commas. So, the clue really needs to read like this:

9, 3, 1, 1/3, 1/9, and so on.

Thanks for getting the rank abbreviations right. It's an AF NCO who's SSGT; in the Army, she'd be SSG and a pay grade higher.

Or *he*. We let boys in the military nowadays, even though they have cooties.

Roy Doty did a ton of advertising, magazine and book illustration in the '50s and '60s and continues to do so today. He's under consideration for Cartoonist of the Year this year (the Reuben award named for Rube Goldberg) by members of the National Cartoonists Society.
JPG, Roy Doty,  doesn't ring a bell, however, Jon Nagy does!

Ellen (#15),

I certainly forgive you. And I hope you are in better health now.

-- jpgaskell
Love is "recommended."

I guess they exploited as much as they could.  There is rarely any news value by showing a person die in an accident.  It was especially callous to show it as the opening story on the first night of the Olympics last night.

Not to take anything away from Ohno, but it's not just a question of quantity; there's also a question of quality. Bonnie Blair had five golds and one bronze; Ohno has two golds, two silvers, and two bronzes. If you use the gold = 3 points, silver =2, bronze = 1 system, Blair has 16 points and Ohno 12. So far.

I don't understand how the games could go on after a man was killed on the luge track - especially after the craven officials had the gall to blame the victim.

The only possible explanation is that there was too much money on the line to cancel the games and stop the machinery of death.

Everyone who watches any part of the games justifies their reasoning, because every person who watches the game makes the advertising revenue more valuable.

Anyone who watches any part of the Olympics is a murderer.
I love Mirai Nagasu.  She has such attitude.  Good on her for defying all expectations of a demure Asian-American little girl.  You rock, woman!!!

Go USA! Let's get this one for Burkie! I remember the US men's volleyball team had an amazing tournament at Beijing and got the gold medal after the coach suffered a heartbreaking loss (his father-in-law was killed by a mad men while in Beijing for the olympic games).

Let's go, USA hockey!

I assume you meant "inclement" weather--not inclimate.

NYT Editor: Yes, it has been caught and corrected. Thanks.

I would have liked to been in the editorial room when they were discussing the dynamics at play here. Since NBC claims a dictatorial copyright to all things Olympics it seemed a bit opportunistic on their part to be the only network that aired such footage. Had they made it available to all networks, perhaps they would have been playing fair.
Or, they just could have done the right thing, which would have been to respect the gravity of the situation and not aired it, or shared it, with anyone.

I think if someone asked they could find a contractor to fix this and put up a thick enough plexiglass wall to protect the athletes from this massive design flaw. If the   I.O.C. could bring themselves to have a spokesperson just ask publicly, a qualified contractor would be there, I'm sure, to make sure no one else gets hurt or worse, before the next race.

I did not find the footage to be offensive at all. It was newsworthy, and important for people to understand why Mr. Kumaritashvili flew out of the track, and how it could be made safer.

If there had been no footage, then the IOC could have declared the track safe, Mr. Kumaritashvili at fault and not done a thing. With the video footage in the public realm, the IOC still declared the track design safe, and Mr. Kumaritashvili at fault, but at least they fixed the design flaw in the track.

My condolences to Mr. Kumaritashvili's family.

Seriously? This is the fix? These pads look like padding from an elementary school gym meant to keep kids from getting hurt playing kickball. Not something to save the lives of athletes travelling 85 + miles an hour on an Olympic luge run down a mountain. I understand that the athletes want to compete but, I can't believe these other athletes are willing to continue racing on this track. Actually I can't believe their coaches, families or the IOC would let them.

I applaud NBC for not showing the footage for the rest of the Olympics.  I think they"ve covered and handled this story incredibly well - and I think this is indicative of the Peacock's number one news division.  They are a classy, smart bunch!

Positively my last comment: the one entry that drove me crazy was James somebody for laws of thermodynamics, and my mind got hung up on James Clerk Maxwell, which happens to be true but not correct for this puzzle. Finally, it clicked -- and the middle name came with it unbidden: James Prescott Joule.

And why am I making much of this? I happen to be a retired physicist, so this was a tad embarassing.

Gotta love those M.I.T. grads, but I'm not sure I agree the clue is wrong.  The degree is Bachelor of Science (Scientiæ Baccalaureus in Latin) whether the school uses BS, BSc, SB or ScB.  It's not a different degree because the school uses the Latin name, is it?  The function of M.I.T in the clue is to signal Bachelor of Science rather than Bachelor of Arts.  Even an M.I.T. grad wouldn't be so nerdy as to argue with a prospective employer: "no, I don't have a Bachelor of Science, I have a Scientiæ Baccalaureus."  Would they?

I forgot to add that otherwise it was a great puzzle, and a welcome challenge from the previous four days of "no-brainers". I filled in all the blanks except the one numbered 42 ... because I spelled the speed skater''s name as Jensen, not Jansen. And I had watched that Olympics too! Oh, well. :-(

My wife generally knocks off the Friday and Saturday puzzles and the double crostic every other Sunday in half an hour to 45 minutes, She tells me the 15-blank strings are usually easier than the shorter ones.

And yes -- was there ever a real "15-stack" -- with legitimate words? That would go in to Guiness' for sure.
I don't get the A or D, but not B or C clue.

It was appropriate for NBC to show the accident footage right after it happened. It was newsworthy and the footage made it clear how dangerous that area of the track was ... mostly due to a lower than needed wall and some unpadded steel girders. That NBC recognized that it is time to move on is to be applauded.
At 90mph I am not sure padding the pole would have helped.

Yeah......to the guy who asked Canada if it was 'worth it?', not every canadian in responsible for every decision made in this country, or: maybe that's what they think in Oregon?  Who can say....but, you see how petty & annoying nationalistic call outs can be?
